translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Self-Punisher
“Fear arose from self-punishment,
see the people who are confused.
I will proclaim the inspiration
as it was conquered by me.
Seeing the people who are trembling,
like fish in little water;🔽Seeing them oppressed by each other,
fear entered me.
The world is full of thorns,
all directions are closed off;
I wanted my own home,
I did not see a place of rest.
Seeing them oppressed right there,
disappointment arose in me;
Then I saw the arrow there,
hard to see, lodged in the heart.
By which arrow one is pierced,
one runs in all directions;
Having pulled out that very arrow,
one does not run or fall.
There the trainings are sung,
those things that are clung to in the world;
One should not be attached to them,
disenchanted with all sensual desires;

analyzed: sikkhe nibbāna mattano  saccaḥ siyā appagabbhaḥ
translated: One should train for one’s own Nibbāna.🔽One should be truthful, not deceitful,
without deceit, without gossip;
Without anger, the evil of greed,
the sage should spread out equanimity.

original: Niddaṁ tandiṁ sahe thīnaṁ,🔽pamādena na saṁvase;
analyzed: niddam tandim sahe thīna  pamādena na savase
translated: Drowsiness, laziness, and sluggishness,🔽he should not live with negligence.
He should not stand in conceit,
with his mind set on Nibbāna.
He should not be led into false speech,
he should not generate passion for forms.
He should understand conceit,

analyzed: sāhasā virataḥ care  purāṇam na abhinandeyya
translated: he should go about abstaining from violence.🔽He should not delight in the old,
he should not generate desire for the new.
He should not grieve over what is passing away,
he should not be attached to the sky.

analyzed: gedham brūmi mahogha iti  ājavam brūmi jappana
translated: I call the flood the great stream,🔽I call speed the running on.
The object is the falling away,
the mire of sensuality is hard to cross.
The sage, having gone beyond the truth,
stands on the island, the brāhmaṇa.
Having given up everything,

original: Sa ve santoti vuccati.🔽Sa ve vidvā sa vedagū,
analyzed: sa ve santo ti vuccati  sa ve vidvā sa vedagū
translated: he is said to be the one at peace.🔽He is the wise one, the knower,
having known the Dhamma, he is independent.
He goes about rightly in the world,
he does not offend anyone here.
If anyone overcomes sense desires,
the attachment in the world that is hard to cross,
he does not grieve or tremble,

analyzed: chinna sotaḥ a bandhanaḥ  yam pubbe tam visosehi
translated: his stream cut, he is unfettered.🔽You should get rid of what is in front,
you should not have anything behind,
If you do not grasp at the middle,
You will go about tranquil.

analyzed: sabbasaḥ nāma rūpasmi  yassa na atthi mamāyita
translated: In all that is mental and physical,🔽One who has no sense of ownership,
Does not grieve over what is not.
He does not live in the world.

analyzed: yassa na atthi idam mā iti
translated: One who has no “mine”
Or anything of others,
Not having a sense of ownership,

analyzed: natthi me iti na socati  an iṭṭhurī an anugiddhaḥ
translated: Does not grieve over “not mine.”🔽Not harsh, not greedy,

analyzed: an e jaḥ sap badhī samaḥ
translated: Not agitated, equal in all ways,
I declare that benefit,
When asked, without wavering.
For one who knows without agitation,
There is no clinging anywhere.
He, detached, having crossed over,

original: Khemaṁ passati sabbadhi.🔽Na samesu na omesu,
analyzed: khemam passati sabbadhi  na samesu na omesu
translated: Sees security everywhere.🔽The sage does not speak of equality,
Or of inequality, or of superiority.
He, tranquil, free from envy,
Does not praise or disparage.”
The Discourse on Self-Punishment is the fifteenth.
